misconceptions.task: Reading numeric grade input
misconceptions.name: Grade is hard-coded instead of read from the user
misconceptions.description: The program never asks the user for a numeric grade and instead assigns a fixed constant value (90) to the grade variable. This means the letter grade output does not depend on user input, contrary to the problem requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can just set GRADE = 90 (or some value) and use that in my conditions, without needing to read the grade from the keyboard.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must prompt the user for a numeric grade and read it from the keyboard using the Scanner (e.g., grade = input.nextInt() or input.nextDouble()). The letter grade logic should operate on this user-provided value, not on a hard-coded constant.
symptoms: The program prints the same letter grade every time regardless of user interaction.
There is no prompt such as 'Enter grade:' followed by a read of that grade.
Scanner is only used to read point coordinates, not the grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion or oversight about connecting the problem requirement ('reads a numeric grade') to the actual Scanner calls in the code, possibly due to reusing code from a different problem (distance between points) without adapting the input logic.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add a prompt like `System.out.print("Enter grade: ");` and then read the grade into `GRADE` using `GRADE = INPUT.nextDouble();` (or `nextInt()`), removing the hard-coded assignment `double GRADE = 90;`.
related_concepts: Using Scanner to read user input
Separating test values from production code
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The only assignment to GRADE is a literal 90 and there is no Scanner call reading a grade; this pattern is unambiguous.

evidence.note: GRADE is assigned a constant 90 and is never read from Scanner; there is no user input for the grade.
Scanner is only used to read coordinates for a separate distance calculation task, not to read the numeric grade required by this problem.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Incorrect boundary condition for A vs B grade
misconceptions.description: The condition for an A grade uses `GRADE > 90` instead of `GRADE >= 90`. As a result, a grade of exactly 90 is incorrectly classified as a B, not an A, which does not match the specified 90–100 range for A.
misconceptions.student_belief: An A grade should be assigned only when the numeric grade is strictly greater than 90, and grades of 90 should fall into the B range.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: According to the problem, the A range is 90–100 inclusive, so the condition for A should be `grade >= 90`. Using `>` instead of `>=` incorrectly excludes 90 from the A range.
symptoms: A numeric grade of 90 would be printed as a B instead of an A.
The code does not exactly implement the required range 90–100 for A.
misconceptions.root_cause: Off-by-one style misunderstanding of inclusive bounds in conditional expressions, or misreading the problem specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the first condition to `if (GRADE >= 90)` so that grades from 90 through 100 all map to A as required.
related_concepts: Designing if-else chains for numeric ranges
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The specification explicitly says A: 90–100; the code uses `> 90`, which is a clear mismatch.

evidence.note: The A condition uses `GRADE > 90` so a grade of exactly 90 falls through to the B case.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for C and D
misconceptions.name: Missing explicit ranges for C and D grades
misconceptions.description: The code does not include separate conditions for C (70–79) and D (60–69). Instead, any grade that is not classified as A or B falls into a single catch-all branch labeled 'C or below', so C and D ranges are not distinguished as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: It is acceptable to group all grades below B into a single category labeled 'C or below' instead of providing distinct conditions and outputs for C and D.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The specification requires distinct letter grades: C for 70–79 and D for 60–69. The if-else chain should therefore include conditions like `else if (grade >= 70)` for C and `else if (grade >= 60)` for D before the final else.
symptoms: There is no condition that checks for grades in [70, 79] or [60, 69] specifically.
Grades in the C and D ranges would not get distinct outputs; they would all be labeled 'C or below'.
misconceptions.root_cause: Incomplete translation of the full grading scale into code, likely from oversimplifying the conditional chain or overlooking the requirement for separate C and D ranges.
misconceptions.remediation_hint:
Extend the conditional chain to include explicit checks for C and D, e.g.:
`else if (GRADE >= 70) System.out.println("Grade: C");`
`else if (GRADE >= 60) System.out.println("Grade: D");`
related_concepts: Covering all specified cases in requirements
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The only branches after B are a single `else` printing 'C or below'; no C or D conditions appear anywhere.

evidence.note: All non-A and non-B grades, including intended C and D ranges, are handled by a single `else` without distinct conditions for 70–79 or 60–69.

misconceptions.task: Correct handling of F (default/else)
misconceptions.name: No explicit F grade output; lumped into 'C or below'
misconceptions.description: The program never outputs 'F' for grades below 60. Instead, all grades not classified as A or B, including those below 60, are labeled 'C or below', which does not satisfy the requirement that F should be printed for grades below 60.
misconceptions.student_belief: Any grade that is not A or B can be grouped together as 'C or below', and there is no need to distinguish a separate F category for grades below 60.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The specification requires that grades below 60 be reported specifically as 'F'. The final else (or a specific condition) should therefore print 'F' for grades < 60, not a generic 'C or below' message.
symptoms: A grade of 50 (or any value below 60) would be printed as 'C or below' instead of 'F'.
There is no branch in the code that outputs 'F'.
misconceptions.root_cause: Overgeneralizing the remaining cases in the else branch and not mapping the lowest range to the specific F label described in the problem statement.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the final branch to explicitly output 'F' for grades below 60, e.g., after handling C and D ranges, use `else System.out.println("Grade: F");`.
related_concepts: Default case handling in if-else chains
Mapping problem specifications to exact program outputs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The only final branch prints 'C or below'; there is no occurrence of 'F' in the code despite the requirement.

evidence.note: The final else branch, which should cover grades below 60, prints 'C or below' instead of 'F', and there is no other branch that prints 'F'.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Incorrect strict inequality for A grade boundary (90)
misconceptions.description: The requirement for an 'A' grade is 90-100. The student uses `GRADE > 90`, which means a grade of exactly 90 would fall through to the 'B' check, contradicting the rule that 90 should be an 'A'.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student confuses the strict inequality operator (>) with the inclusive inequality operator (>=) when checking boundary conditions.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To include the boundary value 90, the conditional expression must be `GRADE >= 90`.
symptoms: A grade of 90 outputs 'B' (due to the subsequent `else if` which checks `>= 80`) instead of 'A'

misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the definition of greater than (>) versus greater than or equal to (>=). Use the correct operator to ensure the boundary score (90) is included in the highest category.

Student with grade 50 gets 'C or below' (wrong—should be F)
misconceptions.root_cause: Incomplete conditional logic. The student did not implement all required grade ranges, instead over-simplifying the solution with a generic catch-all else clause.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add explicit if-else-if statements for each range: C (70-79), D (60-69), and check F last. Example: `else if (GRADE >= 70) System.out.println("Grade: C");` then `else if (GRADE >= 60) System.out.println("Grade: D");` else `System.out.println("Grade: F");`
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Very high confidence—the code explicitly shows only three branches and the final else lumps everything together as 'C or below'. The specification requires 5 distinct outputs.

evidence.note: Only checks for A and B explicitly. The else catches B through F inclusive, outputting them all as 'C or below'. Missing separate checks for C (70-79), D (60-69), and F (<60).
